csvRow: Overall, the biggest problem is that the city's treatment of cyclists isn't coherent. Outside of trails, cyclists aren't allowed to use sidewalks (seriously, has anyone ever even had a problem with cyclists on sidewalks?), motorists don't treat cyclists as legitimate traffic (I've even had police cars illegally pass me in an intersection), bike lanes aren't safe (filled with debris, illegally parked cars, makes cyclists ambiguous traffic, etc), bike-friendly trails suddenly turn into bike-forbidden sidewalks, and so on. Either make it clear that cyclists are legit road traffic and enforce laws equally, or give cyclists all the same rights as pedestrians. If you want the ambiguous middle ground that we currently have, then we need physically separate bike lanes everywhere. I'd be happy to discuss further or be part of a committee to help improve the situation. Brendan Wood (261-4789 or wood@synchroverge.com).

csvRow.What do you think is the most important: Honestly, I think more bike lanes is just one step. The best thing we can do is make the city safer for cyclists so that more people are encouraged to cycle in general. We can do this with clearer signage, clean (not parked in) bike lanes, lots of places to safely lock up a bike (well lit, racks bolted to the ground), and more awareness promoted in the community about cyclists and cycling. More cyclists = safer cyclists.

csvRow: Male (although I'm not sure why this is relevant)

I've thought a lot about the activity of the trail patrol in this city and I think they might actually do more to discourage people being on bikes than anything else. Think about how awesome a trail patrol could be if they carried around maintenance supplies and were trained to help people fix their bikes and promote safety. If they asked people to "keep to the right" and reminded folks to signal. If they offered to grease a rusty chain. I know more people who ride in far less safe spaces just to avoid them than I do who actually go get helmets. The trailway is the safest area in the city for riding. Beyond the trail patrol, I tend to feel strongly that driver awareness and education is the most important thing we can think about in this space. Cars need to know when it's safe to pass cyclists. They need to know to use their turn signals. And cyclists need to know how to use turn signals and safely take lanes when they're riding in the road. There's so much more education to impart to people than "wear a helmet and use lights/reflectors". It won't be until we start to bridge the adversarial gap between motorists and cyclists that we'll see safer riding conditions in our city.

The "Fredericton City Police Park Patrol" are poorly trained, uninformed, and socially illl-equipped to "enforce" safety on the trails.  The single-minded focus on wearing helmets as the leading (and usually only) answer to the complex question of cycling safety inspires no confidence in the municipal government's ability to respond intelligently or with any genuine authority to nuanced matters.   Did you know the "park patrol" in Moncton actually have paramedic training and act as safety ambassadors rather than teen enforcers?  No joke.  One curious effect of the Fredericton approach is to actually push cyclists off the trails and into the streets where they may very well be less safe.

csvRow: Better promotion could be made of the great trail network in the area.  There should be advertised bike circuits for residents and tourists alike.  For instance, there should be one highlighting  Alexander Gibson's accomplishments.  Various monuments and information signs of Mr. Gibson's legacy are spread all over the trail system in no particular order.  I worked at Marysville Place and some of the most interesting paraphernalia celebrating the life of this great man are also there inside and out of the building but are not available for everyone's enjoyments. (As an aside, consideration should be given to establishing a proper Boss Gibson museum and developing an outdoor walking/biking circuit component alongside the more confined artifact/ education facility).   There should also advertised walking/biking circuits in Odell Park and Botanical Garden (some marked trails being labelled easy, intermediate or difficult).  The information centre on the north side portion of the trail should be open for a longer period.

ca\/cityfredericton\/en\/recleisure\/res.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">Fredericton Trai: NONE. Stop paving perfectly good trails. As the pavement wears, conditions for cycling/running become uneven and worse than ever!

csvRow.What do you think is the most important: Make Fredericton flatter. Honestly, this river valley thing is a huge hindrance. Maybe one of those funicular hillside elevator systems like they have in San Francisco.

csvRow: 1) I was only partly kidding about the funicular. A major problem with a city built on a hill is getting up and down the hill. A graduated, safe trail or bike route that lets people switchback up and down a hill to make it more managable would be a huge help. The disjointed set of trails leading from Kimble/Wilsey up to Bliss Carmen school is an excellent example of one such system, on a mix of roads and quiet trails. 2) Fredericton roads and drivers are simple not built for cycling traffic - as a former road rider/frequent commuter, near-misses with cars (including two "grazes" - one that sent me flying from my bike) have left me wary of being on roads with any significant traffic. Bike lanes are no more than painted lines that are too-frequently populated by ignorant pedestrians (especially on Canterbury Drive). I'm not sure that a major initiative to increase commuter cycling is likely to be fruitful, and for recreational use, the current trail system is spectacular.

csvRow.What do you think is the most important: Physically separate roads for motorists and cyclists.

csvRow: As a motorist, reckless cyclists (e.g. not stopping at intersections) is a major safety concern. As a pedestrian, cyclists driving on the sidewalks is also a safety concern.  Other than the trails, many cyclists are uncomfortable driving on the roads.  Several motorists are uncomfortable sharing the road with cyclists. At the very least, there needs to be more education for motorists, cyclists, and pedestrians for what the expectations are for cyclists. Ideally, additional infrastructure for cyclists could be created (e.g., Vienna, where motorists and cyclists had separate roads and traffic lights at intersections).

csvRow.What do you think is the most important: safer access from outside city.

csvRow: As an avid road cyclist I found it difficult to answer question #3. While I am comfortable with traffic, I believe bike only infrastructure would be of benefit to users not comfortable with traffic, and would be beneficial to all. Anything that helps people get out of their vehicles and get on a bike is a good thing. Also as a cyclist of many years I am not convinced bike lanes do much as they are today. A combination of factors makes them unsafe (debris, grates, parked cars). I can say I'm not even sure where they are painted other than a few locations, and they just stop at random points anyway. Cars seem to pass me with much less clearance when they think I'm in a lane of some kind (even just a white line). When I'm more firmly on the road I seem to get more notice and clearance from vehicles. I also seem to get passed when it is not appropriate (i.e. when my speed is same as traffic) when I’m way over in a bike lane, or far to the right. Bad drivers are my largest concern today, not infrastructure. Infrastructure will help those not comfortable with traffic the most (and have biggest impact as far as increasing uptake of active transportation I believe). That being said, I doubt local drivers will be able to correctly navigate streets with additional barriers, as evidenced by their traffic circle confusion.

Comfortable in traffic, but prefer using bike lanes or other bike-only infrastructure

CLEAN (no debris) Bike lanes with NO drainage holes, pot holes, access holes etc.  Sufficient room for car and bike to exist, not just sticking the lane in the part of the road that is impassable by every vehicle.  Bike lanes are often the worst section of the road.  Not allowing cars in the bike lanes would also be good.

Signage for motorists, motorists education of driving with bikes, awareness of distance between car and bike required to be safe.  Cars are very aggressive in this city, and the bike network does nothing to assist driver behaviour and the shear danger to cyclists on the road.  No amount of lighting/reflective wear helps with how close motorists get to the vehicles.  Winter riding in bike lanes is impossible, so driver awareness is essential.

Bike pathways or designated areas are just too few or disconnected.  Bike trails are often stop/start in nature, too many street crossings, and the bike lanes are quite unsafe.  Whenever arriving at an intersection, there is often no designation of where the cyclists can go.  Although I love the idea of a physically separated space for cyclists on the road, this is Fredericton, and funds are limited (and we get a lot of snow), so this is not likely practical.

csvRow.What do you think is the most important: Make cycling more fun and a viable option (no we're going to go exercise, make it a pleasent outing to go to the stores and hangout. I can't get them to exercise for the life of me. Even if they had to bike somewhere to save me!)

csvRow: Change comes very slow to Fredericton and everyone knows it. Everything is a fight and that fight cannot be a deterrent for the city to make a positive change in the environment. People think it's crazy to bike to work or to the store because 'we have cars to drive'. Parking is too inexpensive to the point people drive to the trails to have a leisurely strole on their bikes. How weird is that?! We need change. Not only for our health, but also for the Earth as well as the benefits it gives to the aging population, cycling is fantastic for them because it helps with balance. Not everyone will want to cycle and that's fine but it should not be a city where everyone is so scared to be on the road that they bike on the sidewalk, or that there is a social belief that only vehicles are allowed on the street. I should not be biking and have people yell "you're not a car" at me while I am LEAGALLY allowed on the street. No nonesense either of, cross the bridge on the sidewalk (encouraged by some police officers) because cars are zipping by like 60km/h will get them past the red light up ahead. We need a shift and this is a great start. It just needs to be implemented and pushed for. There is not a strong advacacy group in Fredericton but there is a great need for some intervention to happen with our expanding waist lines... I look forward to seeing what comes out of this!! Stick it to the motorists (in a pleasent, we want to be friends kind of way).

Coming down the hill, with my light on, I hit one of those signs and fell off my bike.  Getting up, I brushed myself off and continued.  I hit a second sign right away and fell off again.  There is no way anyone could have seen those signs with a bike light.  I had minor injuries for a few weeks.

csvRow.What do you think is the most important: More paved trails that are separate from traffic.

csvRow: You're asking about "gaps" and specific points for improvement. The one I notice most is more of a "bigger picture" defect. Bike lanes are nice, and maybe separate lanes are in some sense an ideal; but a problem with them is that if there's no commitment to maintaining them, they're always full of debris. That's the situation in Fredericton. Also, Fredericton's road shoulders seem to be especially poorly maintained, in that they're often very uneven and full of pavement gaps and sunken utility holes and such. Look at Rookwood or Woodstock Rd for example. If the bike lane or farthest right part of the road is uneven and full of debris, a cyclist's safest option is to ride more than 1 m from the curb, which sometimes creates conflict with drivers who don't understand why the cyclist isn't hugging the curb. As a cyclist, I suspect I'd be better off with fewer bike lanes, but with something like sharrows or "share the road" signage on roads that are wide enough to accommodate bikes while allowing cars to safely pass. On Regent St and Hanwell, for example, there are no bike lanes but there's plenty of room for everyone. Also, on the "practical reality" front: the trail patrol. I'd agree that some kind of enforcement of trail safety and etiquette is a good idea, but in practice the people available for hire in that role don't have the skills to be effective. They just annoy people and do sketchy stuff in the middle of the trail, thereby creating more risk. So why not rethink the job, hire students to do something good but slightly easier so they can succeed: trail ambassadors or somesuch.

csvRow.What do you think is the most important: More bike lanes or allow cycling on the sidewalks. Dump the mandatory helmet bylaw... majority of people I know do not want to wear them and studies have found that helmets do not help in most cases.

csvRow: Biking on the road is dangerous. Bikes and cars don't jive well in my mind. If a car hits a cyclist, they can die, the car will be unharmed. But sharing a sidewalk? If a bike hits a pedestrian, there might be a bum? A bruise? Right? I think pedestrians and cyclists are more compatible that cyclists/motorists. However, it is rude to bike on a sidewalk downtown during say, a crowded lunch hour? Then it's best to just get off the bike and walk it for a bit. But like, say it's the evening and you only run into a few people... then the sidewalk can be shared. As long as the cyclist is respectful of their surroundings and the people around them. I guess the problem that necessitates the bylaw is that most people are not respectful. I am very polite when I bike on the sidewalk but that is not always the case. In June of 2010 I saw a truck hit a cyclist near the corner of Westmorland/Brunswick. Truck took a right hand turn really fast, didn't see the cyclist. The girl was bloodied up bad. I was walking on the opposite side of the street... the scene was horrifying though. Only the girls arms were not underneath the truck, then he backed up a bit (with other people directing him) the they tried to pull her out. Blood everywhere. Also, like I said I've had a couple of close calls and cyclists getting hit are in the news almost monthly. So yeah... scary to bike on the road!  Also... please re-think the mandatory helmet bylaw. They don't help. They're styrofoam. They create an illusion of protection. They put out a message the biking is something dangerous when really it would make more sense to wear helmets in a car. Also, adult should be responsible for their own safety choices. Here are some links to read about why bike helmets aren't all they're cracked up to be: //www.howiechong.com/journal/2014/2/bike-helmets   http://www.cnet.com/news/brain-surgeon-theres-no-point-wearing-cycle-helmets/

Facile d'y accéder et d'y circuler hors de la saison hivernale.
Avoir une plus grande distance de déneigement du réseau durant l'hiver et avoir des rues où la neige serait enlevée de l'accotement.
Les accotements des rues devraient être nettoyées plus tôt au printemps et régulièrement pour éliminer des débris de bouteille de verre cassé, surtout au centre-ville.
Le propriétaire de chien devraient garder leur animal en laisse et ramasser les excréments de leur chien même en hiver.

Déneigement du sentier à partir de l'Hôtel Delta en hiver.

Meilleur entretien trottoir du pont Westmorland où il n'y a pas de pente d'écoulement pour évacuer l'eau de la surface, les flaques d'eau s'accumulent sur le trottoir, le nettoyage du sable de l'hiver ne se fait pas avant la mi-juillet.

La promenade Rookwood où la bande cyclable est couverte de flaques d'eau les jours de pluie.

Intersection de Queen et Westmorland où le trottoirs des pavés en briques s'avance en courbe sur l'accotement devant l'édifice TD crée un danger pour les cyclistes qui doivent rouler dans l'espace des véhicules

csvRow.What do you think is the most important: Faire une campagne publicitaire pour inciter les citoyens à être en meilleur forme physique en se déplaçant à vélo, à contribuer à la qualité de l'air et l'environnement. Développer avec la Province du N.-B. des incitatifs pour les fonctionnaires à devenir plus actifs, à choisir le vélo comme moyen de déplacement pour se rendre au travail.

csvRow: J'apprécie que vous puissiez vous intéresser au développement du transport à vélo dans la ville, en toutes saisons. Je pense qu'il est agréable de pouvoir rouler à vélo autant l'été comme en hiver. Être en sécurité est le point majeur. Le développement urbain devrait se faire non pas seulement pour les voitures mais d'avantage pour la sécurité des piétons et des cyclistes.
